docs.lead_paragraph: Former NFL player Sam Adams failed to pay wages and health care premiums for workers at his fitness clubs in Washington state, leaving one employee unable to buy Christmas presents for her children and another to incur massive medical bills after she was diagnosed with cancer, investigators say.

headline.main: Former NFL Player Sam Adams Charged in Wage-Theft Case
headline.print_headline: Former NFL Player Sam Adams Charged in Wage-Theft Case

docs.lead_paragraph: Insurers aren't required to encrypt consumers' data under a 1990s federal law that remains the foundation for health care privacy in the Internet age — an omission that seems striking in light of the major cyberattack against Anthem.

headline.main: Anthem Breach: A Gap in Federal Health Privacy Law?
headline.print_headline: Anthem Breach: A Gap in Federal Health Privacy Law?

docs.snippet: Insurers aren't required to encrypt consumers' data under a 1990s federal law that remains the foundation for health care privacy in the Internet age — an omission that seems striking in light of the major cyberattack against Anthem.

docs.lead_paragraph: Soccer clubs need to take a longer-term approach to the mental health of their players, and not just for the duration of their contracts, the chief medical officer of world players' union FIFPro told Reuters.

headline.main: Clubs Need Long-Term Mental Health Plan: FIFPro
headline.print_headline: Clubs Need Long-Term Mental Health Plan: FIFPro

docs.snippet: Soccer clubs need to take a longer-term approach to the mental health of their players, and not just for the duration of their contracts, the chief medical officer of world players' union FIFPro told Reuters.

docs.lead_paragraph: Several U.S. states are investigating a massive cyberattack on No. 2 U.S. health insurer Anthem Inc that a person familiar with the matter said is being examined for possible ties to China.

headline.main: U.S. States Probe Massive Data Breach at Health Insurer Anthem
headline.print_headline: U.S. States Probe Massive Data Breach at Health Insurer Anthem

docs.snippet: Several U.S. states are investigating a massive cyberattack on No. 2 U.S. health insurer Anthem Inc that a person familiar with the matter said is being examined for possible ties to China.

docs.lead_paragraph: The push came after Anthem, one of the nation’s largest health insurers, said that the personal data of tens of millions of its customers had been compromised.

headline.main: White House Accelerates Drive to Improve Data Privacy
headline.print_headline: A Push to Improve Data Privacy Laws

docs.abstract: White House unveils several initiatives to bolster data-privacy laws, including bid to examine discriminatory pricing on the Internet; push will also include Republican-sponsored bill to protect data collected from students' educational apps.
docs.snippet: The push came after Anthem, one of the nation’s largest health insurers, said that the personal data of tens of millions of its customers had been compromised.

keywords.value: White House Council of Economic Advisers
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: The insurer failed to protect data in its computers through encryption in the same way it protected medical information, and 80 million records were accessed.

headline.main: Anthem Hacking Points to Security Vulnerability of Health Care Industry

docs.abstract: Hacker attack on health insurer Anthem reveals vulnerability of health care firms, which are thought to be lagging behind other industries in protecting sensitive customer data; Anthem failed to protect its computers in same way it guarded medical information that was outside its database; hackers reached up to 80 million records.
docs.snippet: The insurer failed to protect data in its computers through encryption in the same way it protected medical information, and 80 million records were accessed.

byline.original: By REED ABELSON and MATTHEW GOLDSTEIN

docs.lead_paragraph: The first-in-the-nation program using federal funds to buy private health insurance for the poor was reauthorized despite an influx of new Republican lawmakers elected on a vow to kill the hybrid Medicaid expansion.

headline.main: Arkansas: Medicaid Alternative Is Reauthorized for Another Year
headline.print_headline: Arkansas: Medicaid Alternative Is Reauthorized for Another Year

docs.abstract: Arkansas Legislature reauthorizes program using federal funds to buy private health insurance for the poor; passage comes despite influx of republican lawmakers who had vowed to kill the hybrid Medicaid expansion; plan, first in nation of its kind, was offered as alternative to expanding Medicaid under federal health care law.
docs.snippet: The first-in-the-nation program using federal funds to buy private health insurance for the poor was reauthorized despite an influx of new Republican lawmakers elected on a vow to kill the hybrid Medicaid expansion.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: There are strategies for limiting potential damage, although all involve greater vigilance and at least some degree of inconvenience.

headline.main: Protecting Yourself From the Consequences of Anthem’s Data Breach
headline.print_headline: Protecting Yourself From the Consequences of Anthem’s Data Breach

docs.abstract: Steps are discussed for consumers to take to protect themselves in wake of cyberattack on Anthem's database of personal information of up to 80 million people; strategies entail increased awareness and some inconvenience.
docs.snippet: There are strategies for limiting potential damage, although all involve greater vigilance and at least some degree of inconvenience.

docs.lead_paragraph: Health care is a treasure trove for criminals looking to steal reams of personal information, as the hacking of a database maintained by the second-largest U.S. health insurer proves.

docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. health regulators on Thursday approved Medicare coverage for lung cancer screening by low-dose CT, the first time the government health insurance program for the elderly and disabled will pay for such a program of early detection in an effort to save lives.
